_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan-Executive Summary



Facility: Trotter Fertilizer

City: Merna

Contact: Jeff Schaaf

Phone: 308-872-6242



1. Facility Policy



     The owners, management, and employees of Trotter Fertilizer are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, Custer County LEPC, and other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to persons and environment.



2. Facility Information



     Trotter Fertilizer is a small retail facility for plant food and crop protection chemicals. Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored and distributed for the direct application as a nutrient for crop production. Anhydrous ammonia is stored in tanks designed for this purpose.



3. The Worst-Case Release Scenario and the Alternate Release Scenario



     Analysis of the potential off-sight consequences of hypothetical worst-case accidental releases have been addressed in our Hazard Assessment and the information is in our Risk Management Program.



4. Accidental Release Prevention Program



     The facility is in compliance with the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia" and our state regulations covering anhydrous ammonia. The OSHA standard is referenced in this RMP Registration Form, see Section 8.3(b).



5. Five-Year Accident History



    There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have caused any deaths, injuries or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, has THERE BEEN ANY ACCIDENTAL RELEASES resulting in off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, property damage, or environmental damage.



6. Emergency Action Plan



     The facility has:

     a. A written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.38;

     b. Provided state

and local authorities with the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required     under SARA Title III (EPCRA)

     c. If a large release of anhydrous ammonia takes place at the facility, the required response action is to evacuate the area of the spill and call 911 and all applicable emergency response numbers listed in our Emergency Action Plan.



7. Planned Changes to Improve Safety.



     Safety improvements will be an on-going process at this facility. Periodic evaluations will be performed to assess the maintenance and safe conditions of our equipment. There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations at this time.
